feed.title: SAP Community - SAP Business Application Studio
feed.subtitle: SAP Business Application Studio Q&A in SAP Community

entry.title: What end-to-end testing tools are best for SAP BTP (BAS) applications with CDS views and SAPUI5?
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am working on SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) projects deployed on SAP BTP that use CDS views as the data model and SAPUI5 for the front end.

I would like to implement end-to-end testing for these applications. I am familiar with general-purpose tools like Playwright or WebdriverIO, but I am not sure if they are the best fit when testing applications in the SAP ecosystem (especially those with CDS/OData services and SAPUI5).

  • Has anyone successfully used Playwright or WebdriverIO for BAS/SAPUI5 projects?

  • Are there recommended frameworks or libraries specifically designed for UI5 applications?

  • What are the best practices for handling such tests?

  • Any tutorials, examples, or community resources you could share?

Thanks in advance for your insights!

entry.title: Error while using the SAP application generator wizard "@sap/fiori:app generator failed"
entry.content:
Hi Team,

I'm using the wizard to generate a new application from template but at the end, I have an error message :

"""@sap/fiori:app generator failed - env.on(error) An error has occurred, please restart the generator. : TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'sap.app')""

and the application is not created.

I have uninstalled and reinstalled @SAP/fiori:app generator but I still have the issue.

Is there a way to resolve this problem ?

Thank for your help

entry.title: SAP S4 HANA Public Cloud ODATA V4 API throwing 403 error blocked by UCON
entry.content:
We are facing an issue with one ODAT V4  UI type service in S4 HANA public cloud system. Use case is: We have Developed a custom ODATA V4 UI service and created a Fiori elements based UI app in BAS and deployed on BTP Workzone. We have tested this app in Dev system and everything working as expected. But when we transported the same custom service and UI app to Quality system, the ODATA V4 service is throwing 403 Forbidden UCON Blocked error when we try to load the App or load the metadata from browser as well. 

 

Anyone has worked on ODATA V4 UI  API and created a UI app using BTP BAS? Your inputs are highly appreciated. Thanks.

SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA

entry.title: SAP BAS Adaptation Project Layout editor plugin not installed error
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am getting below error, when I am trying to create an extension project using SAP Adaptation Project template.

The Extensibility Project generator plugin was not found in your dev space and it is required for this action. To proceed, please install the <SAPUI5 Layout Editor & Extensibility> extension.

My Fiori Dev space contains SAPUI5 Layout Editor & Extensibility as a predefined one, but still getting above error.

entry.title: how to avoid the unnecessary js calls in the sap fiori custom application
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

Recently i have created a custom fiori application using just smart filter bar and smart table. But when i try to run the application its calling so many js files in network calls and because of that its taking time load the application. 

We already have component.preload.js file for our application which is added automatically after creating project in BAS.

Please suggest how can i avoid the below calls.

KR,

Anji

entry.title: "Deploying Fiori apps in BAS: Object name syntax error in ABAP Deploy"
entry.content:
Hi Community,

I’m currently working on deploying a Fiori component from SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) to an ABAP backend system using the "npm run deploy" command. However, I’m encountering a persistent deployment error that’s blocking progress.

error abap-deploy-task Z_SGM_RRB This syntax cannot be used for an object name

I noticed the deployment log mentions issues with .xlsx files not being recognized, so I have created ". Ui5RepositoryBinaryFiles". After including the file there is no error with excel files and they being recognized.

Has anyone faced this issue before? How can I fix the problem, so the deployment succeeds?

Thanks in advance for any help!

entry.title: How to consume OData service in Fiori app using approuter and destination in Cloud Foundry (404 Not
entry.content:
Hello Community,

I am developing a CAP project on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry. I want to consume an OData V4 service from a Fiori (UI5) application using approuter and a destination.

- Backend (CAP, OData V4):
https://<subdomain>-back.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/odata/v4/invitacion/ReadProveedor

- Frontend (Fiori + approuter):
https://<subdomain>-frontend.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/frontfront/index.html

### Approuter (xs-app.json)
```json
{
"welcomeFile": "/frontfront/index.html",
"routes": [
{
"source": "^/backend/(.*)$",
"target": "/$1",
"destination": "SRV_BACKEND",
"authenticationType": "xsuaa"
}
]
}

 

 

Destination in BTP cockpit

  • Name: SRV_BACKEND
  • URL: https://-back.cfapps..hana.ondemand.com
  • ProxyType: Internet
  • Authentication: OAuth2JWTBearer

 

Frontend manifest.json

"dataSources": {
"backend_odata": {
"uri": "/backend/odata/v4/invitacion/",
"type": "OData",
"settings": { "odataVersion": "4.0" }
}
}

 

Problem

When the app tries to load metadata (/backend/odata/v4/invitacion/$metadata), I receive 404 Not Found.

Accessing the backend service directly via its URL works fine.

What I tried

  • Verified that the destination exists in BTP cockpit and points to the backend URL.
  • Checked the backend service directly (responds correctly).
  • Reviewed approuter logs — I see messages like “Missing internal url for request …”.

What configuration should I adjust in the approuter or the destination so that the frontend Fiori app can correctly consume the OData service via /backend/...?

Any guidance or working examples would be greatly appreciated

I have created a new CAPM application, when trying to deploy the same. I am getting insufficient resources error.

Tried with different accounts getting same error.

entry.title: Unable to use fiori element app inside an iframe.
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I have built a Fiori Element app using local CAP project. I have not used App router (neither external nor managed). The app is deployed and is now available under BTP Cokcpit, HTMl5 Apps. 

 

However when I try to access it in an Iframe (embedding it in Sales and Service Cloud V2 as Mahsup). The app UI loads, but controls donot work.

 

Need help how to enable the app for the Control to work in Iframe.

 

Need Support:

@Kinsbrunner , 

@mike_zaschka

entry.title: React BTP app throwing 403 token validation failed when teying post to backend
entry.content:
Hi,

I have a BTP react app which fetches data correctly from S4 backend through the approuter using destination. However when trying to do a post call, it needs a csrf token which it fetches correctly and passes to the Odata call correctly. However it fails giving with 403, token validation failed.

 

as recommended on another post, I maintained csrfprortection as false in xs-app.json as csrf token validation in my case is maintained by the backend only. 

is there any other config I need to look into, maybe in the destination setvice in mta or the actual destination in BTP, or the destination user role?

entry.title: smart filter bar not visible after smart table personalisation in SAP Fiori custom app.
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We have developed a custom Fiori application using Smart Filter bar and Smart table. 

When we create a custom variant using personalization and set the variant as default the smart filter bar is not visible this happens after we logoff and login again. 

 

We are not seeing any issue if we set the variant as standard. We haven't done any customization in the coding as we just mapped entityset and kept "useperonization=true".

 

KR,

Anji

However, my Fiori dev space already contains SAPUI5 Layout Editor & Extensibility as a predefined extension, but I am still facing the same issue.

entry.title: Vibe Coding with MCP Servers & SAP AI Core: Toward "Coding by Conversation"
entry.content:
Over the past few months, I’ve explored vibe coding — a workflow where you prompt the AI, it generates code, and you iterate. Fast and interactive, yes — but in enterprise projects, context and governance are critical. Without them, hallucinations and mismatched code structures quickly emerge.

This is where MCP servers (Model Context Protocol) and SAP AI Core become essential. Tools like fiori server and cap server allow AI assistants to understand your CDS models, Fiori metadata, and application structure — enabling contextual, reliable code generation.

In this blog, we’ll explore the architecture, practical usage, and enterprise best practices that make AI-assisted coding robust and production-ready.

What is Vibe Coding?

Vibe coding is a transformative approach to software development — essentially, coding by conversation.

  • You describe requirements in natural language.
  • The AI assistant interprets your intent and proposes code patches, scaffolding, or tests.
  • You review, refine, and approve the generated output.

The power of vibe coding lies in freeing developers from repetitive boilerplate tasks, allowing them to focus on high-value work like architecture, user experience, and business logic.

SAP’s reference architecture for vibe coding with Cline + SAP AI Core demonstrates how AI-assisted development can be safe, repeatable, and fully aligned with enterprise standards — turning AI from a helper into a structured development partner.

Core Principles from the SAP Architecture

From the reference architecture, five principles stand out:

  1. Prompt-Driven Development – Express features in natural language, and let the system automatically generate the initial scaffolding.
  2. Context Engineering – Supply LLMs with only the necessary structural context, such as APIs, CDS models, or MCP metadata.
  3. AI-Assisted Test-First Approach – Begin by generating tests, then guide the AI to produce code that fulfills those requirements.
  4. Human-in-the-Loop Governance – Developers retain responsibility for ensuring compliance, performance, and security.

Introducing MCP Servers

MCP (Model Context Protocol) acts as the bridge between your project and the AI assistant.

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is designed to act as a powerful bridge between your project and the AI assistant, ensuring that development is not just driven by prompts but also grounded in real project context. Instead of leaving the AI to guess or hallucinate about how your application is structured, MCP Servers provide it with a deep, contextual understanding of your project.

They expose key elements such as metadata, annotations, models, services, entities, relationships, and queries. This allows the AI to reason intelligently about your project’s architecture, whether it’s related to the user interface, the underlying data definitions, or the service layer.

With MCP servers running, your AI assistant doesn’t hallucinate blindly — it knows your project structure.

Architecture in Action: Cline + SAP AI Core + MCP

Here’s how the pieces fit:

  1. Cline –Your coding agent inside the IDE, mediating prompts, code diffs, and project changes.
  2. SAP AI Core – Hosts the foundation models (Claude, OpenAI, Gemini) in a governed, enterprise-ready environment.
  3. MCP Servers – mcp server expose structured context:
    • UI annotations, metadata, and manifest structure
    • Style guides and constraints
    • CDS entities and services

Workflow:

  • You prompt: “Create a ListReport for SalesOrder with a status field.”
  • AI (via MCP) inspects CDS models and annotations.
  • AI generates the CDS extension, Fiori annotations, and manifest changes.
  • You review, test, and deploy.

This architecture transforms AI coding from a “toy experiment” into a repeatable, enterprise-grade engineering practice.

How to Get SAP AI Core Credentials

  1. Access SAP BTP Cockpit: Go to your SAP BTP subaccount
  2. Navigate to AI Core: Services → Instances and Subscriptions → AI Core
  3. Create Service Key:
    • Go to your AI Core service instance
    • Create a new service key
    • Copy the credentials (clientid, clientsecret, url, serviceurls)
  4. Configure Authentication URL: Usually follows pattern https://{subdomain}.authentication.{region}.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  5. Set Base URL: Typically https://api.ai.ml.hana.ondemand.com (check your service key for the exact URL)
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret
SAP_AI_CORE_AUTH_URL=https://your-subdomain.authentication.sap.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
SAP_AI_CORE_BASE_URL=https://base-ai-core-url
SAP_AI_CORE_RESOURCE_GROUP=your-resource-group

Refer to the screenshot below, which shows how we subscribed to the SAP AI Launchpad application to deploy our model according to the use case. We also created an SAP AI Core instance to obtain the necessary key details required for configuration in the Cline client.

Cline Configuration

  1. Install the Cline extension in VS Code
  2. Open Cline settings
  3. Configure these fields:
    • API Provider: Select "SAP AI Core"
    • Client ID: .clientid
    • Client Secret: .clientsecret
    • Base URL: .serviceurls.AI_API_URL
    • Auth URL: .url
    • AI Core Resource Group: Extract UUID from .appname (first part before the !)

       4. Test with a simple query to make sure it works

Add Server Configurations

To enable AI-assisted coding with full context, add the following server configurations to your cline_mcp_settings.json file. This configuration allows Cline to connect to the MCP servers that expose structured information about your project, including CDS models, Fiori metadata, manifest files, and coding style constraints. By providing these settings, you ensure that the AI assistant can:

  • Understand project structure: MCP servers give the AI visibility into your CDS entities, services, and UI annotations, allowing it to generate code that aligns with your existing models.
  • Follow enterprise standards: Style guides, naming conventions, and other constraints are passed through MCP servers, ensuring that generated code adheres to your organization’s best practices.
  • Generate context-aware code: Instead of generic snippets, the AI can create extensions, annotations, or manifests that fit seamlessly into your project.
  • Improve efficiency and reduce errors: By providing a structured context, the AI minimizes mismatches and hallucinations, letting developers focus on architecture, business logic, and user experience rather than repetitive boilerplate.

With the server configurations in place, Cline can interact with MCP servers in real time, making AI-assisted coding a safe, reliable, and enterprise-ready process.

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "cds-mcp",
      "args": [],
      "env": {},
    }
  }
}

Set Guardrails with Cline Rules (How-To)

Purpose: Provide persistent, project-level guidance — covering scope, coding style, documentation standards, and more — that’s always active in your workspace.

Cline Rules act as a continuous, automated advisor for your development team. By defining guardrails, you ensure that AI-assisted coding adheres to enterprise standards and project-specific conventions. This prevents inconsistent implementations, reduces technical debt, and maintains code quality across the team.

  1. Create a Rule File
    1. In Cline’s Rules tab, click “+” or use the command: /newrule.
    2. Save as a single file: .clinerules at the repo root, or use a folder-based setup .clinerules/ for multiple rules.
  2. Recommended Folder Structure
your-project/
├── .clinerules/
│   ├── 01-project.md      
│   ├── 02-coding.md
│   └── 03-documentation.md  
├── docs/
  • Each file addresses a specific aspect of project guidance: project scope, coding standards, and documentation expectations.

Example Prompt Flow

You: "Initialise an empty SAP CAP application in this folder."
AI: The empty CAP application has been successfully initialised in the current folder

 

You: "Generate an entities sales and sales order items"
AI: The entities is successfully created.

Result: you stay focused on implementing business logic and refining the user experience, while the AI assistant handles all the scaffolding, boilerplate, and repetitive code generation.

Open the Cline application and start the conversation with the above commands — this is where vibe coding truly comes alive, as your AI assistant (powered by MCP servers and SAP AI Core) begins generating context-aware code that you review, refine, and evolve into enterprise-ready solutions.

Once you select the Plan and submit the prompt, Cline (with MCP servers in the loop) interprets your intent, fetches the right CAP/Fiori context, and proposes structured code changes that you can review and refine into a production-ready solution.

You will now see a fully scaffolded CAP (Cloud Application Programming) application generated — with entities, services, and annotations created automatically based on your prompt, thanks to the MCP servers providing structured context to the AI assistant.

Benefits & Caution

Benefits

  • Faster Prototyping and Scaffolding – Quickly generate CAP entities, Fiori views, and annotations without manual boilerplate work.
  • Reduced Hallucinations – Structured context from MCP servers ensures AI proposals are relevant and accurate.
  • Freed Mental Bandwidth – Focus on UX, domain logic, and performance optimization, while AI handles repetitive scaffolding.
  • Aligned with SAP Standards & Governance – Generated code respects enterprise best practices and architectural guidelines.

Caution

  • MCP Servers Are Evolving – Always review AI-generated code before deployment.
  • Complex Business Logic Needs Oversight – Human expertise is essential for transactional integrity, security, and edge-case handling.
  • Prompt Precision Matters – Well-crafted prompts yield better, more reliable results.
  • Governance Remains Your Responsibility – Testing, security, and compliance cannot be fully delegated to AI.

Conclusion

Vibe coding isn’t just about writing code faster — it’s about reimagining how we build enterprise software. By combining AI assistants, SAP AI Core, and MCP servers, we provide AI the context it needs to act as a true development partner.

This approach lets developers move beyond boilerplate work and focus on what matters most: architecture, business logic, user experience, and innovation

Human expertise remains essential. Governance, compliance, performance tuning, and creativity stay firmly in the developer’s hands. But with vibe coding, tedious and repetitive tasks are no longer blockers — they’re delegated.

As these patterns mature, this may be remembered as the moment enterprise development evolved from “writing code” to “designing conversations.” The future of coding in SAP isn’t just AI-assisted — it’s context-aware, collaborative, and human-centered.

entry.title: Authentification required to access the ATO service
entry.content:
Dear Community,

I am trying to deploy a freestyle SAPUI5 application to our S/4HANA Public Cloud system using Business Application Studio. When I run npm run deploy-config, it prompts me to authenticate in order to access the ATO service (screenshot attached). However, when I enter my S/4HANA Public Cloud development tenant credentials, the authentication fails with the error “Incorrect credentials”—despite entering the correct details.

I am currently using a destination with authentication type set to BasicAuthentication.

I found a similar issue  but seems relevant for On-Premise systems, but I’m not sure which role in S/4HANA Public Cloud provides the ATO-related authorization objects. Additionally, the error message “Incorrect credentials” is misleading, since the credentials are valid for logging into the development tenant.

Has anyone else faced this issue? If so, how did you resolve it?

Thank you!

Best regards,
Karthik

entry.title: SAP Service and Asset Manager 2405 - MDK Metadata Deployment Error in SAP BAS Environment
entry.content:
Dear All,

I am currently in the advanced stage of the SAP Service and Asset Manager 2405 implementation and encountering an issue while deploying the SSAM metadata to SAP Mobile Services from SAP Business Application Studio (BAS).

The same metadata was successfully deployed to multiple Mobile Services landscapes approximately four weeks ago and application working fine. However, during the recent deployment attempt, I am facing an MDK validation error in SAP BAS, which is resulting in an incomplete or unsuccessful deployment. Notably, the same deployment process works as expected when executed from Visual Studio Code.

Validation Error:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[10:05:37] -- validating --
Start validating the application /home/user/projects/Dev/AA_Dev_Build_15_v1/SAM.mdkproject/metadata/ssam-metadata with the metadata schema supported in MDK SDK
node:internal/process/promises:392
new UnhandledPromiseRejection(reason);
^

UnhandledPromiseRejection: This error originated either by throwing inside of an async function without a catch block, or by rejecting a promise which was not handled with .catch(). The promise rejected with the reason "Validating the application /home/user/projects/Dev/AA_Dev_Build_15_v1/SAM.mdkproject/metadata/forms-ssam-integration-metadata failed with TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'file')".
at throwUnhandledRejectionsMode (node:internal/process/promises:392:7)
at processPromiseRejections (node:internal/process/promises:475:17)
at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:106:32) {
code: 'ERR_UNHANDLED_REJECTION'
}

Node.js v22.13.1

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Upon analysis, I observed that the Node version in SAP BAS is v22.13.1, whereas in Visual Studio Code it is v20.4.0. Based on this observation, the Node version mismatch appears to be the likely root cause of the issue. From a code perspective, there are no changes or issues—this same custom metadata was last successfully deployed on 20th August across multiple landscape servers.

It is possible that SAP BAS was recently updated to a higher Node version (v22.13.1). Could you please confirm if there is an option to rollback or switch the Node version in SAP BAS to v20.x.x? I would like to attempt the deployment again using the earlier version to validate this hypothesis.

Any insights or recommendations on this would be appreciated.
Thank you in advance.

Regards
Venkata Pavan Vummadisetty

entry.title: Unable to access the OData V4service in the BAS in SAP HANA trial account?
entry.content:
Hi,

I am using the SAP BTP trial account and following the RAP100 to create a RAP application for the Travel app. I managed to create and consume the ODATA V4 service.

The issue is to link it in the FIORI generator as a List report.

I am unable to view my OData service there. Not only the service I created, but also any V4 service that is unable to view. I can view the OData V2 service.

Please advise.

Thank you.

entry.title: Request for guidance to create an Overview Page (OVP) in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Dear SAP Experts,

I have a few questions about creating an Overview Page (OVP) in SAP Public Cloud:

  1. Is it possible to create an Overview Page using the Fiori Launchpad?

  2. Can an Overview Page be created using Business Application Studio (BAS), SAP Web IDE, or Visual Studio Code? Which approach is recommended for SAP Public Cloud?

I am trying to create an Overview Page and cards in a BTP trial account, but no data appears. I have followed several blog posts that describe the steps, yet I still cannot get the OVP to work. Could you please provide a step-by-step guide for creating an OVP in SAP Public Cloud and explain the required BTP configuration in detail.

Thank you very much for your help
